original_data.question: An 11-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother after she observed jerking movements of his arms and legs for about 30 seconds earlier that morning. He has not had fever, cough, or a runny nose. He has been healthy, except for occasional eczema. He was delivered at home in Romania. His mother had no prenatal care. She reports that he has required more time to reach developmental milestones compared to his older brother. The patient's immunization records are not available. He takes no medications. He appears pale with blue eyes and has a musty odor. He has poor eye contact. Which of the following would have most likely prevented the patient's symptoms?

model_response:
This patient has untreated phenylketonuria (PKU). The incidence of this disorder is 1 in 10,000 live births. The patient has a deficiency of the hepatic enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, which catalyzes the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. As a result, phenylalanine accumulates in the blood and is converted into phenylketone (phenylpyruvate) and other phenyl-substituted metabolites. Phenylalanine is an essential amino acid, and its accumulation leads to growth retardation, microcephaly, and mental retardation. The diagnosis is made by demonstrating an elevated blood phenylalanine level. The treatment is dietary restriction of phenylalanine. This requires the elimination of phenylalanine-containing foods such as milk, cheese, and meat. The other treatments listed are used in the management of other disorders.

Levothyroxine is used in the treatment of hypothyroidism. Dietary restriction of phenylalanine prevents the symptoms of PKU. Daily allopurinol intake is used in the treatment of chronic hyperuricemia. Avoidance of fasting states prevents the symptoms of Reye syndrome.

Vitamin K deficiency is not a cause of this patient's symptoms.

###Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.
Female parents, human or animal.
The occurrence of a single contraction or a series of contractions of a muscle.

The act, process, or result of passing from one place or position to another. It differs from LOCOMOTION in that locomotion is restricted to the passing of the whole body from one place to another, while movement encompasses both locomotion but also a change of the position of the whole body or any of its parts. Movement may be used with reference to humans, vertebrate and invertebrate animals, and microorganisms. Differentiate also from MOTOR ACTIVITY, movement associated with behavior.
The superior part of the upper extremity between the SHOULDER and the ELBOW.
The inferior part of the lower extremity between the KNEE and the ANKLE.
The time period between dawn and noon.
An abnormal elevation of body temperature, usually as a result of a pathologic process.

A sudden, audible expulsion of air from the lungs through a partially closed glottis, preceded by inhalation. It is a protective response that serves to clear the trachea, bronchi, and/or lungs of irritants and secretions, or to prevent aspiration of foreign materials into the lungs.
A discharge of fluid from the nose.
Having no significant health-related issues.
Not occurring regularly or at short intervals.
Aspects of peoples' living conditions that may and can impact people's health and/or well-being. These factors may be physical (e.g., housing quality) or social circumstances (e.g., living alone).
A country in southeastern Europe, bordering the Black Sea, between Bulgaria and Ukraine. The capital is Bucharest.
Female parents, human or animal.
Care provided the pregnant woman in order to prevent complications, and decrease the incidence of maternal and prenatal mortality.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.

Deliberate stimulation of the host's immune response. ACTIVE IMMUNIZATION involves administration of ANTIGENS or IMMUNOLOGIC ADJUVANTS. PASSIVE IMMUNIZATION involves administration of IMMUNE SERA or LYMPHOCYTES or their extracts (e.g., transfer factor, immune RNA) or transplantation of immunocompetent cell producing tissue (thymus or bone marrow).
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.
A clinical manifestation consisting of an unnatural paleness of the skin.
A markedly blue coloration of the iris. [HPO:probinson]
Pungent body odor. []
Difficulty in looking at another person in the eye. [HPO:probinson]

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
